summary: This document is a Notice of Claim filed on behalf of two claimants who are victims of the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy. It details the 1996 report made by one claimant to the FBI about Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell's abuse and sex trafficking activities, which the FBI allegedly ignored. The filing accuses the FBI of repeated failures over 25 years to investigate and stop the conspiracy, leading to continued victimization, and seeks damages for the claimants and a class of victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the sex trafficking conspiracy. Described as an employer, abuser, and the person whose criminal enterprise was reported to the FBI in 1996.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Actively involved in the sex trafficking conspiracy, created a 'modeling book' of young people, recruited girls for Epstein, and participated in threats against the claimant.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.context: Businessman close to Epstein; his company Victoria's Secret was mentioned as a purported reason for the 'modeling book'.

persons.name: Eric Fischl
persons.context: The claimant's mentor who advised her to leave Epstein's Ohio residence after the abuse.

persons.name: Steven Hoffenberg
persons.context: Worked with Epstein at Towers Financial; was prosecuted for a Ponzi scheme while Epstein faced no consequences.

persons.name: William Burns
persons.context: Had three meetings scheduled with Epstein in 2014 when he was Deputy Secretary of State, as revealed in a 'trove of papers'.

persons.name: Larry Nassar
persons.context: Referenced as an example of another case where the FBI failed to properly investigate allegations of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Detective Phelan
persons.context: Named as an NYPD individual with knowledge of the claimant's 1996 report to the NYPD.

persons.name: Sharon Churcher
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the facts of the claim.

persons.name: Sergey Brin
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the facts of the claim.

persons.name: Anne Wojcicki
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the facts of the claim.

persons.name: Anne Regan
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the facts of the claim.

persons.name: Miles Alexander
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the facts of the claim.

connections.description: Partners in the sex trafficking conspiracy; Maxwell recruited girls and managed aspects of the operation for Epstein.
Described as 'close to Epstein'; Epstein's Ohio residence was adjacent to Wexner's property.
Epstein worked with Hoffenberg at Towers Financial prior to Hoffenberg's prosecution.
Epstein had meetings scheduled with Burns in 2014, indicating some level of association.
Maxwell sexually abused the claimant, threatened her, and was part of the theft of her photographs.
The claimant worked for Epstein, assisting with art collection and as a receptionist.
Epstein sexually abused the claimant in Ohio and later threatened her.
Fischl was the claimant's mentor and advised her to flee after the abuse.

events.title: 1996 FBI Report
events.description: The claimant reported the Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy to the FBI, detailing sexual abuse, theft of photographs of her sister, the 'modeling book', and threats.

events.title: NYPD Report
events.description: The claimant also reported Epstein and Maxwell to the NYPD's Sixth Precinct. The NYPD advised her the Ohio abuse was outside their jurisdiction.

events.title: Sexual Abuse in Ohio
events.description: During the summer of 1996, Epstein and Maxwell sexually abused the claimant at his New Albany, Ohio residence and stole photographs, including of her partially dressed sister.

events.title: Florida Federal Investigation
events.description: Federal law enforcement in Florida interviewed the claimant and other victims, promising to prosecute Epstein, but instead secured a secret non-prosecution agreement for him.

events.title: Trafficking of Second Claimant
events.description: The second claimant was sex trafficked by Epstein and Maxwell in the Virgin Islands, New York, and elsewhere during the period when Florida authorities were supposedly investigating.

events.title: Federal Prosecutions of Epstein and Maxwell
events.description: The federal government finally prosecuted Jeffrey Epstein and then Ghislaine Maxwell for sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Court Order on CSAM Review Protocol
events.description: A federal district court issued an order establishing a protocol for Epstein's Estate to review discovered media and alert the FBI if potential Child Sex Abuse Material (CSAM) is found.

locations: New York City (Epstein's residence, East 66th Street apartment building)
New Albany, Ohio (Epstein's residence adjacent to Les Wexner's property)
Palm Beach, Florida (location of Epstein's home and jail)
Virgin Islands (location where claimant was trafficked)
Little St. Jeffs (Epstein's island, referenced as a travel destination)
keyFacts: A claimant reported Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell's sex trafficking conspiracy to the FBI on August 29, 1996, detailing abuse, a 'modeling book' of young people, and threats, but the FBI took no action.
The FBI's alleged failure to act on the 1996 report allowed the Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy to continue for nearly 25 years, resulting in hundreds of additional victims.
During a Florida investigation (2005-2008), federal authorities secured a secret non-prosecution agreement for Epstein instead of prosecuting him, granting immunity to co-conspirators.
The document alleges strong circumstantial evidence that Epstein received special treatment, possibly due to being a government informant or his connections to powerful individuals.
The filing references the discovery of possible Child Sex Abuse Material (CSAM) in Epstein's possessions as recently as 2023, indicating ongoing victimization.
